title: Animal track
text:
__notoc__
An animal track is an imprint left behind in <a href="soil">soil</a>, <a href="snow">snow</a>, or <a href="mud">mud</a>, or on some other ground surface, by an animal walking across it. Animal tracks are used by <a href="hunter">hunter</a>s in <a href="Tracking%20%28hunting%29">tracking</a> their prey and by <a href="natural%20history">naturalists</a> to identify animals living in a given area.
Books are commonly used to identify animal tracks, which may look different based on the weight of the particular animal and the type of strata in which they are made.
Tracks can be <a href="Fossil%20trackway">fossil</a>ized over millions of years. It is for this reason we are able to see fossilized dinosaur tracks in some types of rock formations. These types of fossils are called <a href="trace%20fossils">trace fossils</a> since they are a trace of an animal left behind rather than the animal itself. In paleontology, tracks often preserve as sandstone infill, forming a natural mold of the track.
